9.59.text:
Good afternoon to you all and a very, very
warm welcome to the Museum of Australian Democracy

16.08.text:
at Eureka, or M.A.D.E. My main is Kaaren Koomen
and I have the honour of being the Chair of

23.05.text:
M.A.D.E. I would like to at the outset welcome
our dignitaries, City of Ballarat Mayor, John

29.75.text:
Philips, also a board member of M.A.D.E. City
of Ballarat councillors. Ms Lisa Charter,

37.78.text:
federal member for Bendigo, and today representing
the Hon. Bill Shorten, Lead of the Opposition

42.89.text:
and former Parliamentary Secretary for Disability
Services. I know that Bill shares a strong

48.73.text:
passion for the topic of our discussion today.
Gideon Perrot, the Executive General Manager

54.76.text:
of State Trustees – Australian Foundation.
Sue Rolfe, Executive Director of the Arts

61.44.text:
Project Australia. And an especially warm
welcome to our disability leaders photographed

68.00.text:
for the exhibition in the audience today.
Frank HallBentick, Katharine Annear, Joan

75.23.text:
Hume, as well as other disability leaders
in the audience today, including George Taleporos,

82.59.text:
Joel Dean, Sarah Barton, Susan Salthouse and
Ian Parsons. I would like to acknowledge the

92.40.text:
Wathaurung people, the traditional owners
of the land on which we stand today, and pay

96.63.text:
my respects to elders past and present. I am
particularly honoured and humbled to be here

105.78.text:
today amongst such great leaders and such
fighters, who have fought for democracy to

112.62.text:
make the lives of Australians better. I would
like to acknowledge the many groups of people

120.86.text:
who have made this exhibition possible. The
Partnership with the City of Ballarat through

127.63.text:
its Rural Access and Deaf Access Grampians
program, State Government Trustees and the

134.89.text:
Federation for Regional Renewal. And also
the people of the disability community who

143.15.text:
have shared with us their stories, shared
their photographs and allowed us to piece

149.74.text:
together the history of this exhibition. It
is not only important that the story be told

156.18.text:
but it is absolutely inspiring. It is a story
of leadership. It is a story of tenacity and

163.16.text:
perseverance. It is a story about how lives
have been changed. Bringing this together,

169.94.text:
I’d like to say a special thankyou to Ashley
Heenan and Jennifer Forrest as the curators

176.58.text:
of the exhibition. The Museum of Australian
Democracy at Eureka is committed to telling

184.06.text:
stories of democracy, big and small, local
and international. In telling these stories

191.62.text:
we pay our respects to the men and women who
have gone before us. Like the people of Eureka

197.01.text:
who fought for our rights here on this site
160 years ago. Today, in exactly the same

207.69.text:
vein, we are here to celebrate and honour
and pay respects to another group of Australians

213.51.text:
who have carried forward that spirit of challenge
to make our democracy a better place. It's

221.17.text:
been a long journey and it’s been a tough
journey. I would like to briefly take you

226.77.text:
back to the 1960s and early 1970s, a time
when the Vietnam moratorium marchers were

235.65.text:
making voices heard on the streets of Sydney
and Melbourne. And of course the fashions

241.76.text:
of the embroidered flares and the cheesecloth
smocks were also making their brief appearance

247.85.text:
in history. I'm glad some things have not
endured. A lesser known but equally life-changing

255.87.text:
grassroots campaign was taking place at this
time. We now know that around 20 per cent

264.67.text:
of Australians live with a disability. But
for a large part of our history these figures

273.05.text:
and people's lives were hidden from view.
For many years living with a disability meant

279.11.text:
a life sentence in an institution with very
little selfdetermination or access to the

284.85.text:
same rights enjoyed by other Australians.
I'm also delighted and incredibly admiring

295.14.text:
of the work done by people in this room and
elsewhere to make the radical changes that

301.99.text:
have taken place in the area of accessibility
in response to their voices. Early leaders

310.05.text:
in this movement like Joan Hume, John Roarty
and Anne McDonald, to name a few, campaigned

317.50.text:
for the rights to make decisions that other
citizens just take for granted  things like

324.07.text:
where to live, where they want to work, whether
they can study and whether they can marry.

329.98.text:
In recent years that movement turned to the
Every Australian Counts campaign in support

335.34.text:
of the NDIS, Australia's most recent largest
and arguably most important piece of social

342.74.text:
economic reform in our recent lifetime. Here
in our temporary exhibition on the Campaign

349.32.text:
for Disability Rights we start the conversation
of this previously untold story with a series

356.39.text:
of panels which chronicle some of the history
and the milestones in Australian society,

362.97.text:
led by the disability rights movement, led
by the fighters and the leaders. With today's

371.88.text:
official launch of the exhibition we are adding
12 iconic photographs on disability rights

379.36.text:
in our society both past and present, and
the concept is that we will create a national

384.12.text:
honour board of people who have contributed
to this life-changing movement. I am very

391.22.text:
proud to welcome you to this official launch
and invite you after our forum to view the

397.30.text:
panels, look at the photographs and start
contributing to the digital honour board that

403.15.text:
the museum intends to add to and develop over
time and make available to Australians wherever

409.11.text:
they are, both in Australia and beyond. I
know it's a long list, but I would like to

416.10.text:
specifically acknowledge a few individuals
who have made the journey to be with us today

421.01.text:
and who are represented in the exhibition.
I would also like to acknowledge some of the

425.46.text:
other leaders who played such a critical role.
We have with us Frank HallBentick, Margaret

432.93.text:
Cooper, John Walsh, Joan Hume, Lesley Hall,
Gordon Prior, Craig Wallace, unfortunately

442.36.text:
not the late Stella Young, Drisana Levitzke-Gray,
Uncle Lester Bostock, Katharine Annear, Kelly

454.01.text:
Vincent MLC, and Sue Salthouse. Not all of
those people are here today, but they are

460.37.text:
with us in spirit and we acknowledge and we
honour them. It is now my great pleasure to

470.00.text:
show you a message and a video from Senator
Mitch Fifield, the Assistant Minister for

476.67.text:
Social Services, who sent along this message
to us in lieu of being with us today. It is

484.54.text:
absolutely critical that this issue is a bipartisan
issue. We have seen great examples of leadership,

492.51.text:
but to move forward we need all and every
side of government to be part of this, part

499.88.text:
of making the disability insurance scheme
a reality for more people and to improve accessibility

507.06.text:
for people living with disabilities and their
families as we move into Australia's future.

512.53.text:
We are now going to see a short video message.
Unfortunately I could not be with you today

528.20.text:
in person. But I would like to acknowledge
and thank the Museum of Australian Democracy

533.21.text:
at Eureka for curating this exhibition. It
is important to highlight the efforts of those

538.95.text:
who have campaigned for disability rights
over the years. I was pleased to see the exhibition

544.23.text:
specifically acknowledges the work of the
great Stella Young and the “Every Australian

549.09.text:
Counts” campaign. The disability community
suffered a huge loss with the passing of Stella

555.51.text:
late last year. She was a role model for Australians
on how to seize opportunity and never take

562.41.text:
no for an answer. A ceaseless advocate for
a better deal for people with disability.

569.46.text:
She had a unique approach, using charm and
humour to highlight patronising and negative

575.09.text:
attitudes that people with disability put
up with for far too long. I know she taught

581.50.text:
many Members of Parliament, including myself,
a great deal. It’s also important to acknowledge

588.00.text:
the effectiveness of the “Every Australian
Counts” campaign in delivering the National

593.57.text:
Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS). It put
the issue on the national agenda, and garnered

598.74.text:
support from the grassroots which is essential
to have such a significant change gather momentum.

605.64.text:
Disability is fortunately an area where the
Parliament comes together. Where we look to

610.69.text:
the national interest. The Coalition, when
in Opposition, always brought bipartisanship

617.10.text:
to the NDIS. We recognised it as a once-in-a-generation
social policy reform. As the Commonwealth

624.32.text:
Minister with responsibility for the NDIS
I feel very fortunate to have responsibility

630.23.text:
for seeing it become a reality. The recent
Budget demonstrated this Government’s commitment

636.91.text:
to the NDIS, both now and into the future.
It included $695 million for the NDIS in the

645.02.text:
coming financial year. We now have seven NDIS
trial sites around the country. And the NDIS

653.17.text:
is really making a difference in the lives
of more than 13,500 Australians with disability

659.38.text:
and their families, who are now at the centre
and in control of the services that they receive.

664.69.text:
And I recently signed with the NSW Government
for the early roll out of the NDIS in the

671.12.text:
Nepean Blue Mountains area of Western Sydney.
This agreement is great news for around 2,000

677.42.text:
children and young people with disability
and their families. The work in trial sites

683.57.text:
is allowing us to learn lessons and ensure
better outcomes as we roll out the full scheme.

689.79.text:
I am pleased the bipartisan approach to the
NDIS remains. We have the joint parliamentary

697.37.text:
oversight committee where members of all parties
leave their politics at the door and work

702.62.text:
on providing advice and scrutiny to help make
the NDIS the very best that it can be. The

709.44.text:
NDIS will ultimately grow to support 460,000
participants in 2019-20, and I am currently

717.94.text:
working with my state and territory colleagues
on the arrangements for full roll out. All

723.62.text:
governments will continue to work closely
with the National Disability Insurance Agency

729.56.text:
to ensure the full scheme achieves the goals
that we have set to improve the lives of people

734.66.text:
with disability around Australia. But it’s
also important to recognise that the NDIS

740.11.text:
isn’t, and won’t be, the answer or the
solution to everything. All levels of government

746.69.text:
still have to maintain their commitment to
the National Disability Strategy. The Strategy

753.14.text:
seeks to drive a more inclusive approach to
the design of policies, programmes and infrastructure,

759.42.text:
to provide the sort of society, the sort of
community and the sort of infrastructure that

764.21.text:
all Australians are entitled to expect. Thank
you again for the opportunity to talk to you

770.76.text:
today, and I hope many people enjoy the exhibition
over the months ahead. Thanks very much. It's

786.24.text:
now my honour to introduce Lisa Chesters,
who is the federal member for Bendigo. She

792.16.text:
is representing the Hon. Bill Shorten, opposition
leader and, as I mentioned earlier, the former

798.55.text:
Parliamentary Secretary for Disability Services,
who played such a key role in driving reform

804.24.text:
in this sector. Good morning. It's my great
honour to be here today to represent Bill

815.66.text:
Shorten, the Labor leader, the Opposition
Leader. Can I begin by acknowledging the traditional

822.77.text:
owners of the land on which we meet and pay
my respects to their elders both past and

829.02.text:
present. I’ve been asked to read a short
statement from Bill, who couldn't be here

835.69.text:
today. I will confess, though, straight up
that I am someone with dyslexia, so reading

842.06.text:
out aloud is not my strong point. But I’m
going to give it a go: “The Hon. Bill Shorten,

849.44.text:
Leader of the Opposition, member for Maribyrnong,
I'm so sorry I could not be there to join

856.07.text:
you on this exciting occasion. It is an inspiring
and admirable feat for so many hardworking

863.16.text:
people and organisations to come together
for such a worthy cause. I have worked with

870.18.text:
people with a disability and their carers,
family and friends for many years now and

876.90.text:
this exhibition is a wonderful encapsulation
of so many of their stories, their pictures,

882.93.text:
their struggles, their triumphs. The spirit
of Eureka lives on some 160 years later. We

892.80.text:
hold fast to those undiminished principles
of freedom, democracy and equal rights. In

900.04.text:
this context, whilst the National Disability
Insurance Scheme was an enormous step forward,

909.42.text:
we still have many challenges to tackle as
a national family when it comes to ensuring

915.13.text:
that people with a disability are given the
full measure of rights and opportunities.

922.36.text:
This exhibition brings together the important
elements of that ongoing national effort to

928.22.text:
improve disability rights, and marries this
crucial cause with the power and the beauty

934.39.text:
of art. The disability rights movement has
much to be proud of and much work to do. I

941.34.text:
am proud to continue to stand with you and
to work with you as we move forward. My best

947.82.text:
wishes with the exhibition and your ongoing
work, Bill Shorten, Leader of the Opposition.”

956.81.text:
Before going into parliament, I worked with
low paid workers, United Voice, cleaners and

967.35.text:
security guards, early childhood educators.
And Bill Shorten came to speak to us at one

973.09.text:
of our conferences. His words at that conference
have stuck with me today. He stood up and

981.23.text:
said  as he was giving a motivational speech,
"You know, before I went into parliament,

988.82.text:
before I became the Parliamentary Secretary
for Disabilities, I thought that I had seen

995.11.text:
discrimination in workplaces. I thought that
I had seen disadvantage. And then I became

1001.99.text:
the Parliamentary Secretary for Disabilities.
And if you think you're doing it tough, take

1008.27.text:
the time to meet people with a disability,
understand their stories, meet their families,

1014.96.text:
meet their carers, meet these remarkable people
that for too long have been hidden." Those

1022.16.text:
words today I remember them like they were
yesterday. You have a strong friend in Bill

1028.72.text:
Shorten. You have a strong friend in Labor.
Yes, we have that first step, that important

1035.69.text:
step with the National Disability Insurance
Scheme locked in, but what it looks like going

1040.76.text:
forward is the work we now have ahead of us.
Today is your chance, though, to celebrate,

1047.64.text:
to acknowledge your campaign, the work you've
done. You’ve inspired a nation. You’ve

1054.02.text:
reminded us how critical it is to have grassroots
democracy. How important it is for people

1061.12.text:
to have a voice in their democracy. I thank
you for that and continue to be inspired by

1067.36.text:
your work. Never let people like myself or
Bill Shorten or Mitch Fifield forget what

1073.92.text:
our role is when we go to Canberra. Thank
you and congratulations. Thank you very much,

1089.90.text:
Lisa. I now have the pleasure of introducing
Gideon Perrot, who is from our funding partner,

1097.50.text:
State Trustees. These sorts of things  please
come up  these sorts of things are never

1103.87.text:
done by one organisation, and of course I
don't need to tell this audience that. We

1112.16.text:
all have partners and some of those partners
bring some funds with them, and so they have

1117.76.text:
that little special place in our heart. And
State Trustees is one. I would welcome Gideon

1124.59.text:
to make some remarks. Thank you. Now everyone
is imagining that I have money in my pockets.

1131.76.text:
Lisa, congratulations, well done, that was
beautifully read. I'm representing probably

1138.58.text:
not State Trustees but about 450 people who
work for State Trustees and many hundreds

1144.15.text:
of people who have created the State Trustees
Australia Foundation. On behalf of all of

1150.14.text:
those people I want to extend a warm welcome
to all of you and to say how very proud we

1154.10.text:
are as a group to be supporting M.A.D.E. and
helping launch this event. This is actually

1159.79.text:
the second year that State Trustees Australia
Foundation, or STAF as we call it, which is

1165.93.text:
a bit of an unfortunate name, so I will stick
with “the foundation”  the second year

1171.08.text:
we have provided funding, and we are really
excited to be able to visit today and see

1175.00.text:
firsthand what the general bequests of the
people who have supported the foundation have

1180.30.text:
been able to do to make a difference. Our
foundation provides an easy way for people

1187.35.text:
to donate on an ongoing basis. The way it
works is that people give directly to our

1195.07.text:
foundation the money  and that goes into
a pool of money - earned from that is then

1200.13.text:
applied to support worthy causes such as this.
It's a way for people to give a lasting gift.

1207.26.text:
It’s something that we're encouraging all
of our own customers and our staff to think

1212.22.text:
about. So we can provide grants to the community
for years to come. The foundation is also

1218.40.text:
assisting at the moment healthcare providers
and ancillary care providers in a number of

1224.47.text:
projects aimed at collaborating and innovating
across sectors. As an organisation, State

1230.30.text:
Trustees, which is separate to the foundation,
most often get involved with people when life

1238.79.text:
is unfair or life seems unfair to them. For
those people where life may be ended or changed

1246.94.text:
forever, we're trusted help and that's why
we exist. Our affiliation between this, the

1252.23.text:
foundation and our organisation, is something
we're pretty comfortable with. As such, this

1258.05.text:
foundation is one that is close to home for
State Trustees on a number of dimensions.

1262.63.text:
It's one that we're very pleased to support.
We're committed to supporting regional Victoria

1268.24.text:
and hope this foundation grant helps M.A.D.E.
draw even more visitors to Ballarat and experience

1273.63.text:
this wonderful museum and explore the shaping
of our national identity. As you have already

1281.19.text:
heard from Kaaren, the Campaign for Disability
Rights has a proud history, and believe that

1286.28.text:
this exhibition will indeed start a conversation,
a really important conversation, about this

1291.53.text:
important grassroots democracy movement. The
exhibition also gives us an opportunity to

1296.95.text:
pay our respects to those who have faced adversity
and campaigned for a fair go for all Australians

1302.66.text:
living with a disability. Today you will see
a photographic honour roll here at M.A.D.E.

1307.38.text:
– I hope you’ve seen it in the round room
– which features 12 of these leaders, some

1312.77.text:
beautiful photos. While it’s an amazing
exhibition, we hope that you all take time

1317.35.text:
to have a look through it today - one of the
most innovative features of the exhibition

1321.58.text:
is the creation of a digital honour roll.
This will be made available at the M.A.D.E.

1326.27.text:
website and present a number of leaders from
the disability rights movement around Australia.

1332.32.text:
This site will feature more information on
these leaders and why M.A.D.E. has chosen

1335.66.text:
to honour them and their contribution to the
movement. I'm also really excited that a future

1340.99.text:
extension of the State Trustees Australia
Foundation support will be the opening of

1346.05.text:
this conversation to the broader Australian
community, allowing anyone to nominate a person

1351.92.text:
who they believe deserves to be included on
the honour roll. This digital honour roll

1358.98.text:
will become a living exhibition that can evolve
and grow over many years. We believe these

1365.18.text:
heroes of the disability rights movement,
whether they are household names or simply

1369.76.text:
everyday people who really did their part,
deserve to be honoured. It's an honour to

1377.42.text:
see the funding from our foundation grant
program help shine the light on our journey

1382.91.text:
towards greater equality and empowerment for
all Australians and help break down barriers

1388.48.text:
to social inclusion for people with a disability.
So thank you again for having us today and

1394.36.text:
over to you, Kaaren, again. Thank you very
much, Gideon. I would like to echo those remarks

1406.22.text:
in relation to our honour roll. We encourage
you to make your nominations and share the

1413.61.text:
stories that you have, share the people that
have played such a key role in making the

1420.36.text:
changes that we're celebrating today. I also
want to just reiterate the message about M.A.D.E.

1430.17.text:
being both a physical and an interactive digital
museum. It's a very important part of who

1436.36.text:
we are and what we aim to achieve. We want
to reach out to people across the country

1443.79.text:
of all ages, of all stages and have resonance
and take them on a journey to think about

1452.95.text:
issues such as the issues of people living
with a disability, issues of ageism, issues

1462.29.text:
of sexism, issues of other discrimination,
things that have stopped our democracy functioning

1470.11.text:
as fully as it should. So, that is one of
our objectives. Everything that we do we try

1476.78.text:
to also mirror online. And the digital honour
roll plays an important part in that. So thank

1483.47.text:
you again for making that possible. I also
just want to take a moment to say how important

1493.58.text:
it is for you to continue to tell your stories.
For people that may not know someone with

1500.77.text:
a disability or not knowingly know someone
with a disability, sometimes you have been

1506.16.text:
invisible in the past, as you well know. So,
sharing the stories is such a fundamental

1511.92.text:
part of making change. And we are  I was
particularly delighted to meet Rosemary Crosley

1522.68.text:
earlier, who partnered with Annie to write
Annie’s Coming Out many, many years ago.

1527.84.text:
I as a young person read the book. Ever since
I read the book I never felt the same way

1534.38.text:
about people with a disability. I certainly
started to reflect on what it would have been

1539.92.text:
like for someone roughly the same age to live
in an institution. That's just one story.

1545.78.text:
We're now going to move on to another way
of telling stories. I know that book became

1552.27.text:
a movie. We're now going to see a trailer
from a very important movie that has been

1558.36.text:
put together, a film that’s been put together
by Sarah Barton. Sarah is an award winning

1564.04.text:
film maker who’s well known for her work
on a number of films, including Untold Desires:

1570.14.text:
Dealing with Sexuality and Disability, and
No Limits, a television program that looked

1574.86.text:
at living life to the fullest with a disability.
She has now completed a film called Defiant

1582.71.text:
Lives. We’re going to see a short trailer
in a moment up on the screen here. We wanted to share this with you.

1925.10.text: Well Defiant Lives indeed. A fantastic film. I

1929.94.text:
urge you all to see it. And get as many other
people as you can to see it as well. We will

1938.61.text:
now move to a panel session. There will be
two panels. The first panel is about ready

1945.19.text:
to go, as you can see. The first session will
be moderated by Dr. George Taleporos, who

1953.33.text:
is the manager of the Youth Disability Advocacy
Centre. He has a PhD in psychology and honours

1961.40.text:
degree in sociology and has worked in the
Disability Advocacy Centre, amongst many other

1966.48.text:
things, for many, many years. I will hand
over to George and he will manage the panel,

1973.67.text:
and then we will come back to me and go to
the next session. Great. Thank you. How is

1988.37.text:
the sound? Thanks for inviting me. I also
want to mention people who might not have

1999.98.text:
been mentioned so far  and that's Lesley
Hall – who we saw up on the screen. Lesley

2008.64.text:
Hall was an incredible person. Particularly
her work on the NDIS and also many years before

2017.10.text:
that – we just saw on the screen her work
around changing attitudes, particularly when

2027.66.text:
it comes to the charity model of disability
and saying that we don’t want to be pitied,

2033.15.text:
we want to be valued and we want our rights
respected. I wanted to mention Lesley Hall.

2040.44.text:
When Ashley asked me to come along today I
said, ‘Oh, yeah, that should be okay’

2046.65.text:
and then he said, ‘It's in July.’ I said,
‘You want me to come to Ballarat in July?’

2060.12.text:
I said, ‘No.’ I said, ‘I just can't
cope with that level of cold.’ Anyway, a

2078.39.text:
few weeks later he rings me up and he says,
“George, guess what?” I said, “What,

2086.38.text:
Ashley?” He said, “Bill Shorten’s coming
to our opening.” I said, “Sweet. I’ll

2096.27.text:
see you there, then.” I'm a very big fan
of Bill Shorten. The first time I saw Bill

2110.45.text:
Shorten speak as the Parliamentary Secretary
for Disabilities it was at a conference in

2115.79.text:
Melbourne. It was in early 2007? It was a
long time ago. Probably late 2007. And Bill

2131.27.text:
Shorten did something that no other politician
in his role had ever done. He managed to get

2140.77.text:
people with disabilities to get serious about
campaigning. He gave us a challenge. He said

2152.03.text:
in no uncertain words that we need to start
to unite and we need to start to get our voices

2164.41.text:
heard. And we answered that call. And seven
years later we have a commitment to a National

2173.48.text:
Disability Insurance Scheme. And I’m not
one to piss in the pockets of politicians,

2179.15.text:
but in this case I honestly believe that he
played a very important role in uniting us

2188.23.text:
and in ensuring that we have our voices heard
on a national stage. So thank you, Bill. I

2199.67.text:
have the pleasure of introducing a panel who
together have a long history of involvement

2211.04.text:
in the disability rights field. Frank HallBentick
has been doing this activism thing for, what,

2219.84.text:
30 or 40 years now, Frank? I forget. And Leah
van Poppel – I don’t know if that’s

2232.24.text:
how I pronounce it. But close enough. Leah
currently works at the Australian Federation

2242.42.text:
of Disability Organisations and manages the
NDIS loop I believe. So please make them welcome.

2255.10.text:
Frank, I might start with you, if that’s
okay? What do you think led to us finally

2270.79.text:
getting the NDIS up, when you consider that
it's something that was originally mentioned

2280.08.text:
as far back as 1974 with the Whitlam government?
Why did it take so long? Yes. That to you,

2290.22.text:
Frank. Well, firstly, can I start off with
your statement about Bill's statement at the

2297.84.text:
conference, which I was also at. I was quite
pissed off with Bill, because lobbying politicians

2307.47.text:
is not something that we all hadn’t done
over many, many, many years. Disability service

2316.89.text:
providers had done the same. So to have a
new boy on the block get up there and tell

2322.69.text:
us we weren’t lobbying properly or we weren’t
doing something properly – I was quite pissed

2329.94.text:
off. But politicians, like other people, like
to be loved. So what we needed to do was not

2341.36.text:
do individual lobbying, as we’d been doing
previously, but to get a grassroots swell.

2347.32.text:
Which the NDIS campaign and The Every Australian
Counts campaign did, where people with disabilities

2357.14.text:
went to their local politicians and just talked
to them about what could happen if we got

2366.07.text:
the funding to live independently. And politicians
found themselves nodding thankfully and having

2376.38.text:
pictures taken, but then in the end found
themselves being pushed into something where

2385.37.text:
they had to commit themselves. You talk about
1974. Since the early 70s when the Americans

2395.56.text:
started to get personal funding to move out
of institutions and into their own homes and

2405.51.text:
apartments back in Australia we saw that this
was the way we wanted to go as well. And we

2416.87.text:
came together as advocacy groups, which were
all about human rights, but politicians didn't

2425.75.text:
want to know about human rights. They just
wanted to feel good. Most of the big charities

2433.17.text:
helped them feel good - in funding the big
charities. But the services that they provided

2440.84.text:
were all around large institutions or institutional
living or employment and accommodation. What

2450.33.text:
we wanted was to be independent and live our
own lives. We wanted to have families. We

2457.49.text:
wanted to live in the community. We wanted
public transport that we could actually get

2462.87.text:
onto and use. So over the years we fought
for this. With the election of the Labor government

2476.58.text:
in 2008, and the 2020 Summit and the big thinktank
about how Australia could be better, one of

2485.27.text:
the ideas that almost didn't make it out of
the summit  it seemed to be forgotten about

2491.64.text:
there for a while  but finally brought up
for the final paper by Tanya Pliberseck was

2504.53.text:
the National Disability Insurance Scheme.
And people started to look in a different

2512.63.text:
way at what that should be. So, no longer
were they all out lobbying around whether

2521.76.text:
it was a charity, a nice thing to do for people
with disabilities – whether it was our

2527.31.text:
human rights. Those issues had really taken
hold with politicians. But now a new idea

2536.04.text:
came along to show the economic worth. So
don't worry about human rights; if it's cheaper

2543.94.text:
for us to live in the community than it is
in institutions, that’s a good goal. I don’t

2551.08.text:
know. Can I just maybe challenge you on that.
I think one of the key things from there

2556.14.text:
you might want to jump in on this  is that
we were  the idea of an NDIA was partly about

2568.96.text:
people being afraid of becoming disabled themselves
and what if there had been some kind of way

2578.99.text:
of ensuring that if they did become disabled
there would be some form of insurance or something

2584.00.text:
that would be there to support them. And we
saw images of people and families and children

2591.51.text:
saying, "This could happen to your child."
Do you think maybe there was a danger that

2599.91.text:
we fell back into the pity approach with the
media that was occurring at the time or were

2608.59.text:
you confident that that wasn't going to happen?
I think there was certainly a lot of concern

2618.57.text:
at the time about, well, disability has always
been portrayed as about this thing where you’re

2626.30.text:
rattling the tins and as Frank just said,
getting money for charities. How are we gonna

2632.27.text:
do this? And people were concerned about that.
Because one of the drivers of the Every Australian

2637.12.text:
Counts campaign, one of the things that came
out of Bill's statements to the sector about,

2642.19.text:
you know, you guys need to get organised,
you guys aren't campaigning properly. Everybody

2648.54.text:
bristled at that but then what happened was
we got what’s called the National Disability

2653.53.text:
and Carer Alliance. That was formed by some
key people. It was formed by Bruce Bonahady,

2662.70.text:
the man who took the idea to the 2020 Summit that
Frank just talked about, and who is a family

2672.96.text:
member, with family members who have disability.
Rhonda Galbally, who has a disability herself

2678.66.text:
and has run businesses and worked in fairly
high-profile places. And by the leaders of

2688.13.text:
National Disability Services, at the time
Ken Baker. Carers Australia, I think at the

2693.23.text:
time Joan Hughes, and the Executive Officer
of the Australian Federation of Disability

2701.07.text:
Organisations, who was at the time Frank's
sister. Is she older than you? No. She’s

2709.02.text:
my younger sister. Younger? Oh, that explains
a lot. Lesley Hall. So, I think there was

2720.35.text:
concern among the community of people with
disabilities about all three of those groups

2725.76.text:
coming together, about, you know, because
there had been this historical imbalance of

2733.38.text:
service providers who’ve held the money,
people with disabilities have often felt that

2738.70.text:
families and carers are listened to and service
providers are listened to before they are

2744.32.text:
listened to. And not necessarily because service
providers and families are evil or mean to

2751.18.text:
do bad things sometimes. But because that's
the way our system has worked. And because

2755.71.text:
our society over a long period of time has
seen people with disability as powerless and

2763.32.text:
passive. So there was real concern that that
would happen, I think, and there was a real

2769.37.text:
risk that it might. I remember Stella Young
coming up to me during one of the conferences

2774.70.text:
and saying, "George, what are we going to
do about this?" I said, "What are you referring

2782.50.text:
to?" She said, "I'm really worried that we
are actually being manipulated in a way so

2790.65.text:
that people feel sorry for us. For so many
years we have tried to combat that” and

2797.58.text:
like we saw on the screen, to fight the ‘spastic
society’ approach to disability. But I think

2806.69.text:
that there came a time when we united, when
we realised that there was an end goal in

2817.16.text:
sight and that we were willing to keep our
eye on that goal and not be I guess fractured

2827.07.text:
and put into a situation where we were fighting
amongst ourselves. Can I ask, back to you,

2836.79.text:
Frank. Was there a moment in the campaign
when you actually thought maybe this is going

2843.31.text:
to result in something? Maybe we might win
this time? No! There never was a moment. And

2853.16.text:
there still isn't. We really shouldn't delude
ourselves into believing this is achieved

2859.16.text:
and doesn't need to be lobbied for in the
future. I love the conspiracy theory. Look

2865.46.text:
at what has happened to Gonski and the education
reforms? We really have to be on our guard

2872.76.text:
continually to make sure that this happens.
So what will it take? You’re a hard man,

2878.52.text:
can I tell. What is it gonna take for you
to be convinced? We need to continue to be

2885.98.text:
involved. We have set up a big bureaucracy
of the NDIA. And like all big bureaucracis,

2894.72.text:
slowly it becomes not about the clients or
the people with disabilities but about its

2901.38.text:
own survival, about its staff, about the bureaucracy,
about administration rather than about promoting

2910.72.text:
the full independence of people with disabilities.
It becomes about budgets. So we really all

2918.60.text:
need to take responsibility for continuing
to be involved and to keep on top of that.

2926.90.text:
At the moment we still have bipartisan support
from all politicians, which is great. We did

2936.55.text:
see before the last election there was a bit
of, "Hmm" and toing and froing about that,

2943.84.text:
and finally they came on board. But again,
that is what we've got to continue with. We

2953.76.text:
have got to make sure that the politicians
that are involved are still committed to it.

2962.57.text:
And not just the idea but the actual funding
of it. This could go terribly sour if future

2976.76.text:
budgets don't provide the funding. And if
we look at the budgets within our own state

2982.80.text:
governments – mostly disability services
is funded at the moment ... at times you will

2988.36.text:
get a good minister and you’ll get some
good funding; next time around it's all scaled

2994.39.text:
back. It’s a constant fight. Absolutely.
We need to stay vigilant. We need to stay

2999.96.text:
vigilant, because of the fact that – all
we need is someone to come in and say, "This

3009.69.text:
is something we need to cut back and funding
needs to be redirected somewhere else." As

3016.78.text:
advocates and as a community we need to definitely
stay vigilant. I just want to mention that

3024.81.text:
we are open to questions from the floor. We
have an open mic, if anyone has a question

3032.68.text:
for any of us on the panel. Oh, we have a
question. Down to my left. Can you maybe

3046.89.text:
say your name. Hi. Congratulations, you mob.
I'm Janet Dawe. I’m a member of the board

3058.97.text:
of M.A.D.E. and also for the time being the
CEO of the Transport Accident Commission,

3064.18.text:
which the Productivity Commission had made
its recommendations on the NDIS as more of

3071.07.text:
an insurance scheme to make sure  modelled
on the TAC to make sure that there would be

3076.95.text:
money on the balance sheet to look out for
the long-term needs. I hear what you are saying

3082.02.text:
about bureaucracy, but do you think the model
is appropriate as it is at the moment? Leah,

3088.89.text:
do you want to respond? Okay. Just for those
in the room who don't know about the Productivity

3098.95.text:
Commission report  I will take a step back
before I answer the question and just explain

3103.25.text:
that a little bit. One of the key things that
happened after the idea bubbled up at the

3110.75.text:
2020 Summit for an NDIS was that the then
Rudd government committed to a Productivity

3119.68.text:
Commission inquiry into disability care and
support in Australia. And the Productivity

3127.65.text:
Commission is an organisation that is funded
by government but separate to it, but does

3133.17.text:
a lot of detailed economic research for government.
I think the reason that the Productivity Commission

3141.59.text:
was critical was because it laid the groundwork
in a couple of ways. They did a lot of the

3147.64.text:
detailed economic thinking around, okay, how
much money needs to go into this, what is

3154.77.text:
the need for disability supports in Australia?
They did a lot of research into what was happening

3162.63.text:
in all of the different state and territory
systems, because everything had been different.

3166.60.text:
There were different rules everywhere. So
they did a lot of research. But the other

3170.47.text:
thing that was really, really critical about
the Productivity Commission report was that

3178.35.text:
it was formed after having two rounds of hearings,
hearing directly from people with disabilities

3185.49.text:
and their families about the impact of the
current disability system on their day-to-day

3191.70.text:
lives. That was crucial in both formulating
a sense for the Productivity Commission of

3198.09.text:
just how critical this was and what the face
of disability supports was in Australia. But

3204.18.text:
also in raising the consciousness of people
with disabilities and families around the

3208.53.text:
country about how it is that we could go about
enacting change. It was a process of empowering

3215.95.text:
people to speak up about the state of disability
services in Australia and to be a bit of a

3222.65.text:
focal point for people to come together and
go, "Yes, they is something we can start talking

3228.19.text:
more about and working together on." Do I
think the Productivity Commission model is

3233.96.text:
an appropriate model? I think the Productivity
Commission put a lot of thought and effort

3239.65.text:
into thinking about the model and into making
sure that it would be workable. I think how

3245.80.text:
it's implemented matters. And what we learn
from the trial sites that are happening around

3251.69.text:
the country at the moment matters as well.
Because it's one thing to write a document

3256.36.text:
and to think about something in theory and
another thing to put it in place in reality.

3261.08.text:
I think it was a good, important beginning
step and it’s a solid foundation, but we

3266.16.text:
also need to learn as we go. I suppose, you
know, at one time there was the talk about

3278.77.text:
a Medicare levy being the funding source for
the NDIS. In the end it was chosen that it

3287.01.text:
would go into general budgeting. Correct me,
but there is a levy that's now part of the

3297.73.text:
Medicare Levy. So every person who pays tax
will pay I think it's 1 per cent of their

3307.96.text:
0.5? I thought I would round it up. Let’s
just make it 1 per cent and then we’ll have

3315.97.text:
nicer wheelchairs. That amount does not provide
the entire funding needed for the scheme.

3328.43.text:
Sue, another question? Sue Salthouse from
Women with Disabilities ACT. I think that

3349.31.text:
one of the things with where the Productivity
Commission had been disappointed is that they

3354.95.text:
did envisage the NDIS as being run from an
independent agency. I think that the model

3362.44.text:
that we have with it being seated within government
has put certain constraints on what happens.

3372.93.text:
Nevertheless  so the comments about bureacratising
the system are very real and I think that's

3382.44.text:
why we do need to be extremely vigilant and
radical and that those pictures we saw just

3391.02.text:
now of the 70s demonstrations in America ... and
four years ago I saw the same happening in

3402.16.text:
Korea. I think we need to tuck those away
inside our heads and not too deeply, because

3408.37.text:
the NDIS is the biggest reform and something
that we have a responsibility to make sure

3414.67.text:
it happens as well. I'm sure everybody in
the room echoes those sentiments. Sorry, that's

3424.85.text:
a statement, not a question. Leah? I just
want to respond to something Sue said. I’m

3445.83.text:
deaf-blind so sometimes I'm going to turn
to people on the panel or look at the screen

3449.81.text:
to see whether I'm interrupting someone or
whether it's me that needs to be speaking.

3455.16.text:
Go on, Leah. I wanted to just respond to something
Sue said. She talked about advocacy being

3464.13.text:
- sometimes we do need to be radical and sometimes
we do need to be strong. I think one of the

3471.13.text:
interesting things about watching the National
Disability and Carer Alliance was that there

3478.10.text:
were two people – and two women  with
disability involved. They were Ronda Galbally,

3485.46.text:
who is someone who operates very politically
and who is what some people in advocacy might

3494.56.text:
call an inside of the tent person, someone
who speaks inside the room for people with

3500.00.text:
disability. And then we had Lesley. Anyone
in the room who knew Lesley would know that

3504.97.text:
she is a classic advocate, a person who stands
up, she had a particular way of looking over

3513.38.text:
her glasses and just saying to people, "No!
That's not acceptable." I think it's really

3521.45.text:
important that when we talk about campaigns
for people with disability we talk about the

3526.21.text:
place for both styles of advocacy. We need
to have the people who are inside the tent

3533.04.text:
and we need to have the people who are prepared
to stand up and just say, ‘No, this is ours.

3538.17.text:
This is us. We control this. Because we are
the people whose lives it affects.’ When

3544.41.text:
it came to the campaign for the NDIS one of
the most effective things at the top levels

3552.08.text:
certainly was knowing when to use each of
those things. Also, I would add to that - in

3559.67.text:
the early days of the campaign a number of
national disability service providers did

3568.49.text:
come together and provide about $5 million
I think it was in a war chest to help the

3577.58.text:
campaign, which meant that they were in control of
the early days of that campaign. In the early

3593.39.text:
days for people with disability that very
much looked like, again, this was something

3599.37.text:
that was taking off without people with disabilities
having a big say in it. Certainly when Lesley

3607.01.text:
got involved as CEO of AFDO, she brought that
back and brought into that alliance quite

3621.96.text:
a strong voice on behalf of all national groups
and people with disabilities, which was respected

3628.60.text:
by those others there. I think what helped
to have that level of respect was that after

3634.82.text:
a time the alliance  the members of which,
you have service providers, who are very used

3642.79.text:
to having control over the way services for
people with disability work. You have got

3647.44.text:
families who are saying, "We can speak. We
know really well what people who can't speak

3652.34.text:
up for themselves want", and then you have
people with disabilities, who feel like they’ve

3657.47.text:
been maybe displaced in the conversation for
a long time by both of those groups. It’s

3662.47.text:
really hard to get all of those groups together
and to build something like this campaign.

3668.35.text:
One of the things that they did that was critical
was to, A, listen to Lesley and Rhonda and,

3674.68.text:
B, to bring in someone to help mediate the
conversation, and that someone was Kirsten

3680.51.text:
Dean, the Executive Director of the Alliance
for a time and who was very involved in the

3688.08.text:
Every Australian Counts campaign and making
it real on the ground. I have been told we

3693.96.text:
have run out of time. But thank you so much
to our panel members. Thank you, Leah. And

3706.11.text:
thank you, Frank. I just wanted to end with
a comment and something I think that has not

3722.40.text:
been mentioned, and that is the power of social
media and the power of the internet. The fact

3731.01.text:
that we had this campaign in a time where
it was possible to communicate your support

3739.82.text:
for an issue by simply pressing "like" on
Facebook – I think suggests that it is

3747.11.text:
something that we need to acknowledge as being
a big part of the force behind the campaign.

3754.35.text:
Social media and the internet. That's all
from me. I will hand back to our MC. Thank

3772.34.text:
you. (APPLAUSE) Okay. Thank you very much,
George. That was a great overview. I certainly

3781.42.text:
took away some important little messages.
I just want to recap. Please feel free to

3789.03.text:
move away if you need to. Just for the audience,
Frank and Leah told us the importance of getting

3796.99.text:
the economic arguments right and using the
Productivity Commission, which is a very important

3803.67.text:
lesson. And Leah told us that both styles
of advocacy are important. Both people that

3811.87.text:
are inside the tent, the suits, and those
that are outside it. Sometimes taking a more

3818.34.text:
radical approach. And George just reminded
us of the importance of social media, the

3825.62.text:
importance of Facebook to get our message
across. These are tools that we can all use.

3831.26.text:
It's just another example of how our world
is changing. But sometimes the fundamental

3838.78.text:
issues of fighting for our rights remain.
The overall message I took away from that

3844.85.text:
session came from Frank in particular, who
said that the battle is not over. We do need

3851.19.text:
to continue. (APPLAUSE) We're now about to
start our second panel. This panel is on where

3869.25.text:
we have come from and where we are heading.
It's going to be chaired by Sarah Barton.

3879.32.text:
Sarah is our wonderful film maker whose film
trailer we saw just a few moments ago. She

3889.42.text:
will be joined by Stephen Giani, Joan Hume,
Katharine Annear and Sue Roff. I will just

3901.47.text:
hand over to Sarah. Thank you, Sarah, for
leading the session. There has been a slight

3918.87.text:
change of panel lineup since I got my notes,
but I can run with that. Before we start the

3926.45.text:
panel, I just wanted to clarify a couple of
things about my film. It was said that the

3933.80.text:
film is finished and ready to see. Unfortunately,
much to my frustration, that's not yet the

3939.01.text:
case. I began working on this film doing some
initial research back in 2009. And at that

3945.98.text:
time the idea of making a documentary about
disability rights was deeply unfashionable.

3951.19.text:
It’s kind of remained so until really just
the last year or so. But along the way I have

3958.56.text:
had a lot of support from individuals and
organisations. But we are still completing

3966.02.text:
the film. The film is currently being edited,
and we're hoping that Screen Australia will

3971.32.text:
tip in some funding to allow us to complete
the film to a really high standard. If that

3976.45.text:
doesn't happen, we will find another way.
But fingers very tightly crossed at the moment.

3982.77.text:
I think that the trailer is a really good
showcase for the film. I'm very hopeful that

3987.81.text:
the wise people who know nothing about disability
at Film Australia will actually just love

3993.61.text:
it on its own merits as a film. Hopefully
the film will be completed very, very soon.

3999.34.text:
But I just wanted to clarify that it's not
completed. It's a bit of a premiere for the

4005.35.text:
trailer here today. Then I will go home and
put it on YouTube and spread the word. Feel

4012.60.text:
free to share it with people. I want people
to know that the film is coming. The film

4018.62.text:
really talks about that journey from institutions
out into the community. One of the things

4024.47.text:
that is actually very difficult about making
a linear narrative film that is a little bit

4029.24.text:
easier to do in an exhibition that's not linear 
I found that there were certain topics that

4035.58.text:
can't be squashed into that linearity. When
an audience watch a film they expect a story

4041.54.text:
with a beginning, middle and end. Inevitably
there are themes that I would – I would

4047.58.text:
love to be able to put so many stories into
this film. My last screening of a cut  I

4054.11.text:
got some activists and some film maker friends
to look at a cut. They just said, "There is

4060.32.text:
too much in there. We can't get our heads
around it all." Sadly, the film will not have

4066.11.text:
every wonderful story about the disability
rights movement. But we have to remove things

4072.84.text:
to actually make a compelling narrative. But
what we can do today and with this exhibition

4077.91.text:
is a lot more of those stories can be told
in a way that doesn't need to have that kind

4086.25.text:
of logic. On the panel today, Joan Hume is
one of the people who appears in the film;

4092.44.text:
not in the trailer. You don’t make it into
the trailer, but – I’m not gonna be famous?

4098.30.text:
But you are in the film, definitely, Joan.
I went to Sydney and filmed a wonderful interview

4103.90.text:
with Joan. Then we had several good glasses
of wine afterwards and a bit more chat. You

4109.64.text:
really took up the Sydney angle of the anti
Miss Victoria protests that Lesley got started

4117.79.text:
and really took that into Sydney. That was
something - it started here in Melbourne?

4123.99.text:
Unfortunately we didn’t get to disrupt the
meeting, because they – the Ms Australia

4128.91.text:
quest had already been wised up to the fact
that we ‘can’t allow those radicals in

4137.24.text:
the door’, that we were as radical as the
Victorians. We weren’t even allowed in the

4140.35.text:
door, but we had the protest outside where
the Miss Australia Quest was being held. This

4147.63.text:
is back in 1983. One of the funniest recollections
was a bus saying ‘spastic society’ or

4159.76.text:
something like that pulled up. Out streamed
people all dressed up to the 9s in tuxedos,

4170.66.text:
women in long flowing gowns. And heaps of
jewellery, sparkling. Extremely able bodied,

4178.06.text:
very glitterati-type people. Many of them
were dignitaries invited to the event. The

4185.81.text:
irony of it was – here was this bus flashing
all of these signs saying disabled people,

4193.04.text:
handicapped people or whatever the terminology
was. I think in those days it was ‘spastic

4197.17.text:
society’. I don’t think the word ‘retard’
was there, but it was probably there in spirit!

4203.71.text:
Including my local member  who I happened
to know because he was a local sportsperson

4210.75.text:
who had taken out my older sister at one stage.
I was handing out pamphlets. He looked at

4222.66.text:
me. He looked at pamphlet and said, "You're
a disgrace!" I thought, ‘What have I to

4229.70.text:
be disgraceful about?” Anyway, so all of
the beautiful people poured out of this bus

4234.55.text:
with this sign saying - and not one disabled
person was actually on that bus. To me that

4239.46.text:
kind of captured the heart of what that campaign
was all about. It was kind of a mirror opposite

4249.61.text:
of what the disability rights movement – nothing
about us without us. Everything about them

4257.03.text:
and nothing about people with disabilities.
We could raise money on their behalf, but

4265.43.text:
not let them be part of the party. And represent
an image of the beautiful people to raise

4268.20.text:
money so that we could have beautiful people
being spokespeople for us, patting people

4275.49.text:
with disabilities on the head, telling them
to shut up and sit in the ‘back room where

4283.05.text:
you belong’, and we were not to be – when
was it that you ever saw somebody with cerebral

4288.80.text:
palsy actually win a Miss Australia Quest?
I think things changed later on, but the Miss

4292.41.text:
Australia campaign died, because people with
a disability said, ‘We don't want you to

4297.82.text:
raise funds that way. We don't have a problem
with you raising funds, but there are much

4300.66.text:
more dignified ways of doing it.’ And we
didn't want that. That kind of message of

4312.06.text:
protest that Lesley started, yes, we took
up, and I think it resulted in a different

4318.06.text:
way of fundraising and a different way of
enabling and encouraging and incorporating

4328.24.text:
people with disabilities to make decisions
about their own lives. Steve Giani, you have

4337.80.text:
been around as an activist for a while on
the Melbourne scene. I'm interested to know

4343.17.text:
some of the issues and maybe tactics that
you would remember as some of the earliest

4350.44.text:
things that you were involved in. And what
were the issues and what were the tactics

4355.11.text:
used? I just wanted to start by saying it's
wonderful to be here and wonderful to be here

4366.63.text:
with all of you. The big thing for me and
the place that I started was around trying

4378.41.text:
to dismantle and be a part of dismantling
the service system model that we had, that

4388.51.text:
people with disabilities had in Australia.
And it did start here in Victoria. It was

4395.54.text:
really around some key people saying, ‘We
want this thing called attendant care. We

4404.42.text:
want people who are working with us in our
homes, working with us wherever we are, providing

4411.45.text:
us with daily living skills, with reading,
with assistance to access goods and services.

4420.66.text:
All of those things. We want that to become
a part of a natural way of working for Australia

4429.23.text:
and for Australians. So, the first thing I
had to do was try and learn about that. Because

4437.37.text:
I had only just come back from overseas and
I had been living there for quite a while,

4444.66.text:
running my own business. When I got back and
got involved in this movement, the movement

4450.78.text:
around attendant care, I was flabbergasted.
There are some people in the room that taught

4457.21.text:
me a lot in those days. And some that aren't.
But there is one I will tell you a story,

4464.80.text:
a very quick story, about one of the women
who really helped me understand what attendant

4471.16.text:
care meant and how important it was. And if
there are children here, I'm sorry, in advance.

4479.73.text:
A woman called Annie McDonald, I was told
to speak to her because I would learn a lot

4485.98.text:
more about attendant care and how important
it was to have a different way of delivering

4492.00.text:
services to people outside of institutions
and institutional care. So I went and met

4499.33.text:
Annie or she came to our offices at the then
Attendant Care Coalition. Annie spoke by touching

4507.19.text:
a cardboard board thing that had words and
letters on it, I think; I don’t see very

4513.61.text:
well. So, somewhere is there interpreting
it for me. I said to Annie, "Tell me about

4519.15.text:
attendant care? What difference has it made
to your life." She just touched out I think

4528.29.text:
I said that needed to research it and understand
it better – and she tapped out, "I would

4535.88.text:
be fucked." I said, “Oh, great.” “Help
me understand what, ‘I would be fucked’

4545.85.text:
means. I still don't quite get attendant care.
Is it a sexual surrogate thing or whatever?’

4552.13.text:
And then she said, ‘No. They would lock
me up again." And that was where my conversation

4569.86.text:
with Annie and my thinking began, around what
it means to have a service system and a model

4578.39.text:
that does something other than deal with us
in an institutional way. No better person

4587.12.text:
to teach you than Annie McDonald. He was forthright
and succinct and she always told it like it

4596.37.text:
was. Sue, you are the CEO at Arts Project.
Arts Project has been around a long time supporting

4606.15.text:
artists with disability to make art. I was
saying to you just before that due to a family

4614.39.text:
connection I was recently at the funeral
of Leo Cousin, who is one of the most well-known

4621.14.text:
artists to come out of Arts Project. The thing
that I was particularly interested in with

4625.27.text:
Leo – and you could make this more generally
about Arts Project – but the thing that

4628.82.text:
always struck me about Leo and his art and
from his family perspective was that there

4634.87.text:
were a number of artists from Arts Project
Australia that really moved beyond the disability

4640.70.text:
world. And their art spoke to art collectors
and art lovers around the world. I think there

4648.15.text:
was some involvement from Stuart Purvis at
Australian Galleries that really brought it

4652.47.text:
out from being a disability project to being
genuinely about art. I think that's really

4660.65.text:
an interesting sort of story and an interesting
model I think for what really disability rights

4666.91.text:
wants  to be a part of the community. Would
you like to talk a little bit about how Arts

4673.36.text:
Project fits? Sure. Our founder, who sadly
I never met, Myra Hilgendorf, was quite an

4679.95.text:
extraordinary woman. My involvement with disability
has really only been since I came to Arts

4686.53.text:
Project for the past six years. I have learnt
so much in that time. Myra had a daughter

4696.17.text:
Joanna who had a fairly profound intellectual
disability. Myra was an artist herself and

4703.09.text:
thought the art that Joanna was creating was
really valid and great art. It was back in

4714.13.text:
the 70s. We're 41 years old this year. So,
she gathered, as people do  a group of like-minded

4721.55.text:
people around her and went and knocked on
the doors of the art professors at universities

4725.03.text:
and said, "Look. Put it all on the floor.
I want you to have a look at this. Tell me

4731.24.text:
what you think of this." And got a real groundswell
of support. For the first probably 10 years

4736.92.text:
of Arts Project Australia it was simply about
artwork made by people with intellectual disabilities

4744.26.text:
being exhibited and curated in a professional
manner. That collection is about 400 or 500

4750.76.text:
works. There were three exhibitions in that
time. Myra is one of the people I want to

4756.25.text:
put on the digital history roll. But then
the next person I would like to put on is

4763.40.text:
our founding director Cheryl Day, who was
a member of that committee and an art teacher

4769.37.text:
at Janefield. When you look – we still have
this collection of work. When you look at

4772.20.text:
it today, number 1, mostly the last name of
the artist is never included in the art work

4779.90.text:
for fear of embarrassing their family. Number
2, it's deteriorating, because they are really

4787.83.text:
crappy materials that the art work has been
made with. That is because mostly they were

4793.96.text:
made by people who were in institutions and
mostly it wasn't deemed to be a profitable

4799.30.text:
or worthwhile activity. Cheryl said, "Let's
start our own studio and make one of the philosophies

4807.85.text:
good-quality materials.” That's number 1.
Number 2, “We won't teach anyone to do anything.

4813.75.text:
They will make art the way they want to make
art.” It started slowly. I think Kew Cottages

4820.23.text:
was still going at that point. I know there
was a group who came from there. So, we kind

4826.28.text:
of moved through the whole period of deinstitutionalisation,
and some of our artists have been with us

4833.73.text:
for 25 years-plus, so quite an extensive time
to build up a repertoire and an art practice.

4843.22.text:
I’m really pleased - part of our mission
is to advocate for inclusion within contemporary

4846.99.text:
art practice. I have to say that that’s
certainly been achieved and hopefully will

4852.95.text:
be achieved in an even greater fashion, because
of Myra Hilgendort, because of Cheryl Day

4860.19.text:
and because of the remarkable artists that
come in and teach us so much every day about

4866.00.text:
what they do. Katharine, you're a new generation
of disability activist. You’re part of the

4874.33.text:
new younger generation. Of course, everyone
is so saddened still by the loss of Stella

4882.73.text:
Young. In that community, many people have
begun to step up and have their voices heard.

4894.77.text:
I knew Stella very well for many years. We
worked very closely together. But there was

4900.87.text:
a point where it was like there was only one
voice for disability in our media, and that

4905.78.text:
was Stella's voice. And, you know, to look
at what has happened since she died  there

4913.94.text:
have been a lot of other people who have been
able to step up. I'm not in any way trying

4918.00.text:
to present that as a plus, but I’ve noticed
there's a lot more diversity of voices. So

4926.14.text:
that's one thing. But the other is  Katharine,
I'm interested to know for you and your peers

4933.25.text:
what you feel the issues are. We have heard
about the NDIS, but really that's just the

4938.31.text:
tip of the iceberg. It's a much broader slate
of issues and ideas we're dealing with now.

4946.95.text:
I have awesome genes; I'm not a young person.
I have been doing this for 25 years. I think

4961.16.text:
one of the things we have got to remember
is that it's not just about the NDIS. NDIS

4968.21.text:
is currently a solution to an economic problem.
We have not really seen the social impacts

4975.32.text:
of the NDIS at all yet. Maybe on an individual
basis and an anecdotal basis we’ve seen

4983.65.text:
some changes in people's lives. But we certainly
have not seen the wave of attitudinal change

4990.47.text:
that is needed in society to accommodate everyone
living with disabilities. I think that's a

4999.08.text:
challenge for the future. People will be getting
out of their homes and moving from more institutional

5006.66.text:
settings like groups homes to independent
living, and that is part of the goal, but

5011.87.text:
is society ready for that? No, they are not
a all. So that's important work of young advocates.

5020.95.text:
One of the other important things is that
young people need to recognise the legacy

5027.73.text:
and the gift of the elders of the movement.
Some people might like to hit me over the

5036.97.text:
head if I call them an elder Joan is just
hitting me now - for people who didn't get

5045.43.text:
that visual. I say that with the utmost respect.
Like an elder in an indigenous community – they

5052.30.text:
are elders that went before us who we need
to recognise and pay homage to who did some

5059.52.text:
radical and awesome things in the 70s and
80s and that we can only aspire to do in the

5067.78.text:
future. I think that kind of activism will
still be needed. We do have the very powerful

5073.51.text:
tool of social media. We have seen that powerful
tool of social media, for want of a better

5081.32.text:
word, cripple an attempt lately at a campaign.
The Stella's Challenge debacle you will remember as

5091.07.text:
being a failed homage to the legacy of Stella.
But I think that that whole process has been

5101.28.text:
a lesson in itself in terms of what tools
have been available to people to enable us

5107.92.text:
to have a voice. When you look at social movements,
we're in an interesting time. We have done

5115.74.text:
all of our initial advancement and coalescing
and our bureacratising. We are a bureacratised

5124.47.text:
movement. We have disabled people’s organisations,
our supports have been bureacratised. You

5130.88.text:
know what happens in social movements after
bureacratisation? It's called decline. That's

5139.05.text:
why the previous panel’s point about being
vigilant is important, lest we fall into decline

5147.37.text:
after our bureacratisation. That's what the
study of social movements tells us. ‘We’ve

5154.56.text:
had a go at the problem. It seems partially
fixed’ and people take their hands off the

5159.99.text:
wheel. The challenge will be, with bringing
young people into the movement, is being more

5167.10.text:
flashy than Instagram and more friendly than
Facebook. So, we need to sort of meet people

5174.55.text:
at their level and entice them into something
exciting. In my role as the chairperson of

5183.56.text:
the organisation, I work with the Autistic
Selfadvocacy Network. We have a lot of young

5188.90.text:
people wanting to come on board who are very
social media and computer savvy who want to

5198.10.text:
make contributions to a movement, but they
get frustrated by our bureaucracy. It's a

5206.68.text:
balancing act. It's embracing I guess some
of the qualities that Stella had in terms

5218.58.text:
of the media savvy and vivaciousness, and
not putting them off with our bureaucracy,

5228.37.text:
and I guess our tendency to making things
a little bit boring. We also want people to

5244.25.text:
deeply understand the legacy. So it's a balancing
act. And with every movement  it's the same

5250.50.text:
as the gay rights movement. People generally
these days in developed countries experience

5259.36.text:
rights that are not and could not have been
dreamed of even 30 to 40 years ago in the

5265.09.text:
gay rights movement. You can walk down the
street holding your partner's hand. Obviously

5273.55.text:
we know in the US now you can legally marry
in all 50 states. So the movement is similar

5281.59.text:
in that there are lots of things that young
people take for granted like access to buildings,

5288.51.text:
access to media, and a general creeping attitudinal
change that we need, on the one hand - we

5299.12.text:
have some awesome stuff that we're doing.
But we have to remember where we have come

5305.31.text:
from. That’s a constant balancing act. I
think that's a good point about where we could

5309.75.text:
be going and things we might not even imagine
are possible. This morning my daughter said,

5316.00.text:
"Does the minister for disability have a disability?"
I said no. She said, "What's the point of

5322.18.text:
that, then?" I thought to myself, "Well, there
will be a time hopefully in not too many years

5328.92.text:
when the minister for disability will have
a disability" because they will have some

5331.65.text:
insight into it. It is important to acknowledge
people who have gotten there and how they

5338.38.text:
– like Kelly Vincent in South Australia.
How they’ve managed that role. Being a friend

5346.68.text:
of Kelly’s – it’s not all glory. It’s
a lot of guts and determination and a lot

5352.56.text:
of people who lobby you. And politicians in
the room will understand that you lobby constantly

5359.14.text:
over different people’s needs. It's about
having the skills and being savvy and also

5367.23.text:
being recognised for those skills in your
own right. That's part of the problem in going

5375.99.text:
up against TEDX  people with disability who
experience social barriers in everyday life

5385.94.text:
were not recognised for the skills in their
own rights. They were still very much "othered".

5393.37.text:
You just wouldn't do that with other minorities.
You would never come up with a campaign that

5398.99.text:
said, "Go and ask a black person what it's
like to be black." I think the journey still

5408.16.text:
is for the rest of the community to actually
understand what the issues are and how to

5417.26.text:
make people with disability part of the solution.
Unfortunately we are very close to running

5423.69.text:
out of time. But I really do want one or maybe
two questions. Because I think it's a real

5430.39.text:
shame to have a great panel like this and
not have the opportunity for one or two quick

5435.20.text:
questions. Does anyone want to ask a question
from the panel? Or do you just want to rush

5439.95.text:
off to afternoon tea and the exhibition. Yes,
we have a question over here. The microphone

5454.92.text:
is coming. Deb Watson. I want to know who
will campaign for the people who don't fit

5459.02.text:
into the NDIS criteria? It was really interesting
to hear the minister acknowledge in his video

5465.20.text:
presentation that the NDIS at best will only
deliver something for 450,000 to 470,000 people

5478.94.text:
at best. The interesting bit is that if the
statistics are right there are 5 million

5485.47.text:
of us. So that's 10 per cent roughly of who
we are in this country. It was interesting

5493.01.text:
and I think very brave of him to say –
and I am not usually applauding something

5500.42.text:
that he says  but it was brave to say that
the NDS is more important for many of us than

5510.31.text:
the NDIS. The NDIS is really important, of
course. But the NDS is the thing that will

5516.95.text:
allow the other 4.5 million people with disability
in Australia to access our lives in the community.

5528.84.text:
And I think it's absolutely fundamental. Something
that organisations like a lot of those that

5534.62.text:
are represented here today  and AFDO and
others  will really need to be vigilant about

5542.60.text:
and fight. And WIDA and others that are here
- fight strongly for. You are absolutely right

5550.22.text:
that the NDIS is an important but small part
of the solution. The solution actually lies

5557.88.text:
with the whole of the Australian community
understanding what is needed and being willing to

5562.94.text:
have action. And certainly that's something
that we were talking to the operators of Stella's

5570.27.text:
Challenge at TEDX, saying, ‘Why don't we
challenge all of your business connections

5575.53.text:
to do something about unemployment in the
disability community?’ This is not a government

5579.50.text:
handing out more money. You have a network
of a whole lot of employers out there, business

5586.92.text:
connections in the Sydney world of do-gooders.
Challenge those people to actually do something

5593.39.text:
about employment for people with disabilities.
Don't just ask someone on the street what

5597.17.text:
it's like to live with a disability. That
won’t do anything for anyone. But more jobs.

5601.74.text:
It's about constantly seeing those opportunities
for everybody to make a difference. Can we

5607.79.text:
squeeze in one more question? In the early
70s - ’74 to ’78 - quite a few key organisations

5622.85.text:
were started, Arts Project, Footscray Community
Art Centre, Arts Access Victoria, 3CR community

5631.07.text:
radio, all activist grassroots organisations.
Do you think there is another groundswell

5636.64.text:
at this point? We can't just say it was Gough
Whitlam. We could, but there was something

5642.48.text:
happening then where a lot of agencies started.
Besides the NDIS what do you think is going

5649.41.text:
on at this point, that there is more of a
groundswell or what is motivating that? Tony

5657.92.text:
Abbott! No, seriously, the narrowing of everything
and the move towards conservative approaches

5664.36.text:
to governance and the like. On the other hand,
you have some fantastic tools with social

5670.40.text:
media and organising ability through social
media. What we are seeing is really those

5680.91.text:
organisations you talked about that came about
in the 70s were still a lot about people

5688.12.text:
doing for people with disabilities, not with.
Or people with disabilities doing things for

5694.04.text:
themselves. At the moment we're seeing more
of a grassroots movement towards people with

5700.89.text:
intellectual disability and cognitive impairment
and autistic people forming their own advocacy

5707.42.text:
organisations. Victoria has a great legacy
of selfadvocacy for people with intellectual

5713.92.text:
disability. But I think because of new ways
of communicating through modern technology

5720.55.text:
people who previously did not have the voices
or the ability to use their voices  people

5728.60.text:
who may not have spoken or may not have had 
may have had many, many social barriers. Those

5740.23.text:
barriers are being lessened through technology,
and we're hearing more of their voices. We're

5744.68.text:
also hearing the voices of young people who
have gone to mainstream schools and experienced

5751.68.text:
mainstream education who are now coming back
to a sense of community when they find other

5760.18.text:
people with disability through places like
the Youth Disability Advocacy Service in Victoria,

5766.77.text:
where people can coalesce again together after
living separate lives. So, there are lots

5772.84.text:
of things that are feeding that fire. It's
the 21st century and we have some big decisions

5780.18.text:
to make about reproductive technology and
whether we want to become cyborgs or have

5787.00.text:
people alter our genes or eradicate us. That's
just around the corner. We're all thinking

5795.41.text:
about that. Some of you may not be, but I
know we are in our little groups, because

5801.80.text:
this is very real. There is a very real issue
when the federal government funds large research

5811.76.text:
cooperatives and the majority of money goes
into finding a cure for something that we

5819.07.text:
actually value as integral to ourselves. There
are lots of big debates to have still that

5824.26.text:
have nothing to do with care and support but
more to do with selfdetermination. Can I add

5834.77.text:
to that discussion around the arts organisations 
certainly on social media there is a lot of

5840.10.text:
connectedness. There is a desire for people
to be involved. I don't see financial support

5849.14.text:
coming for those  I think there is a lot
of desire for the organisations to consolidate

5853.58.text:
and have less organisations, which I'm not
convinced is necessarily a good thing. Anyone

5860.58.text:
interested in the creative side of life 
Creative Victoria is currently consulting

5866.93.text:
about their strategy and the way forward.
They have a section in their consultations

5874.31.text:
online which is around diversity and inclusion.
Now, it's my mission to get some engagement

5881.45.text:
around the screen industry. Because Film Victoria
has just become part of Creative Victoria,

5885.95.text:
which could be a good thing for disability
on screen. I am certainly interested in a

5894.09.text:
contribution around that. But I think that's
an opportunity for anyone interested in getting

5900.89.text:
Creative Victoria to be more actively engaged
with disability  there is an opportunity

5906.81.text:
until July 17th to put in a submission. I
would urge people to do so because the more

5913.01.text:
submissions they hear around the idea of disability
the more likely they are to do some action

5918.76.text:
on that. Unfortunately we have run out of
time. I would like to thank all of our panellists

5924.58.text:
for being here today. Joan Hume, Katharine
Annear, Sue Roff and Steve Gianni. I think

5932.99.text:
we're going to look at the exhibition. (APPLAUSE)
Thank you very much. We wish you all the best

5946.28.text:
in getting the last stage of the film up.
I will talk to you about that afterwards.

5951.43.text:
I know the people at Screen Australia. So
let’s see what we can do. Also, thank you

5958.82.text:
from M.A.D.E. for the panel. I thought there
were some great little gems. To recap, Joan

5965.94.text:
talked about some dignified ways of fundraising,
and beauty pageants certainly are not one

5970.56.text:
of them. Steve talked about the 5 million
people living with disabilities and what happens

5976.66.text:
to those who are not covered by the NDIS.
Sue talked about the importance that art can

5982.50.text:
play. Katharine reminded us that it is not
just about the NDIS. It is important that

5988.54.text:
young people recognise the legacy and gift
and pay homage and respect to those who have

5993.80.text:
come before and done some of the heavy lifting,
and in many ways that's what M.A.D.E. is about,

5999.90.text:
to actually give a venue for that respect
and honouring. You also warned us to beware

6009.58.text:
of bureacratisation, because that's when movements
start to fall into decline. Don’t take your

6017.68.text:
hands off the wheel. An important lesson for
all of us. And I think Sarah raised the issue

6027.97.text:
of does the minister for disability have a
disability. The next thing that came to my

6034.76.text:
mind was, is the minister for Indigenous affairs
an Indigenous person? Is the minister for

6041.30.text:
women a woman? There's a bit of a pattern
here of people speaking for others and perhaps

6049.24.text:
from a less informed point of view. Even if
they are informed about it, they bring a different

6056.46.text:
perspective from someone actually living that
