experience. Thank you again to the panel.

6065.12.text:
You can either stay there or go back to your
seats. Finally today we have the Mayor of

6079.32.text:
the City of Ballarat, Cr John Philips, who
is also a board member, a very valued board

6084.37.text:
member of M.A.D.E., who will make a few remarks
before closing this afternoon. Thank you,

6098.83.text:
Kaaren. To start off with, we should congratulate
both panels for the work they've done this

6106.68.text:
afternoon again. I would like also to begin
by acknowledging the traditional custodians

6116.46.text:
of the land, the Wathaurung people of the
Koolan nation, and pay my respects to their

6121.22.text:
elders both past and present. I think it's
appropriate that I acknowledge Ms Lisa Chester

6127.07.text:
MP, the federal member for Bendigo. Great
to see you here in Ballarat. Gideon Perrot,

6132.79.text:
the executive general manager of State Trustees
Australia Foundation. M.A.D.E. director Jane

6139.29.text:
Smith. M.A.D.E. chair Kaaren Cooman and the
rest of the board here as well. The City of

6146.43.text:
Ballarat councillors - I'm not sure if we
have too many of them here this afternoon.

6150.16.text:
Welcome. Members of the project steering committee.
Exhibition writers, photographers, story contributors,

6160.20.text:
the team of Conexu Foundation. I think it
was really nice to be acknowledged  the two

6167.57.text:
Auslan interpreters who have done a great
job here this afternoon. To Vicdeaf, and to

6176.10.text:
ladies and gentlemen and to everyone here.
I would like to as I say, thank the panel

6183.86.text:
members for their thought-provoking forum.
And thank you for all of you attending today's

6191.25.text:
official launch of Grassroots Democracy, the
Campaign of Disability Rights exhibition.

6197.09.text:
As Mayor of Ballarat, it's my great pleasure
to be here at this momentous occasion. For

6203.19.text:
the first time, the historical disability
rights movement has been examined by a museum

6209.84.text:
in Australia. The City of Ballarat is proud
to have contributed funds to this project

6215.81.text:
and is delighted to work with the Museum of
Australian Democracy in Eureka and continue

6222.04.text:
that legacy by exploring the stories of Australians
past and present who have campaigned for equal

6230.12.text:
rights and a fair go for all. This exhibition
provides long overdue recognition for just

6238.10.text:
some of the key figures in our disability
sector. People who have campaigned to have

6243.52.text:
their rights recognised. Just as the miners
fought for this site 160 years ago to have

6251.73.text:
the ordinary man's voice heard. And of recent
times, many people living with a disability

6258.59.text:
have worked tirelessly to provide access to
services, employment and selfdetermination.

6266.07.text:
The council recognises the works with people
living with a disability in our community.

6273.71.text:
We are proud to support the work of different
programs within the council such as Rural

6278.95.text:
Access and Deaf Access Grampians. I note Ashley
Heenan, who has been a tireless advocate in

6286.17.text:
all of the time I have been on council. Well
done. The City of Ballarat Disability Advisory

6301.17.text:
Committee was established in 2004 to advise
council of the local issues people with disability

6307.72.text:
face in relation to council services and infrastructure.
It is chaired by a councillor, the committee

6315.72.text:
is made up of people with a disability, service
providers and council staff. Their focus and

6322.70.text:
work is an example of the people's participation
in leadership roles and democratic processes

6330.65.text:
within their own community. The committee
established networks and facilities and local

6337.03.text:
partnerships to address the issues, establish
networks and facilitate local partnerships.

6346.27.text:
It is also working towards building more inclusive
communities for all. I would like to thank

6354.19.text:
everyone who has worked so tirelessly on the
exhibition. It wouldn't have been possible

6359.59.text:
without you. I know that M.A.D.E. has hopes
and plans for this exhibition to tour the

6365.88.text:
country. It is an important story to share
and has national significance. So it is now

6374.90.text:
my great pleasure on behalf of the City of
Ballarat to officially launch the exhibition.

6383.44.text:
I think I'm allowed to say I now close this
official part of the proceedings and invite

6391.76.text:
you all to exit the theatre and join me to
view the exhibition, which is located in the

6397.85.text:
Cafe and Tower areas of the museum. Thank
you, one and all.
